Wow ... just finished it and I am speechless. Absolutely fantastic game. The story has great pace, unpredictable, did not expect the end. The action is fantastic as well. If you're tired of all the 'assembly line' FPS shooters .. this one is definitly for you.

here's my review for Bioshock 3/Infinite:

overall : 98/100
 (i would say there is a small stuffs to add to this game to make it a 100, one of them is to make it LONGERRRR!!)

art and graphics: 10/10
-realistic but yet cartoonish style of graphics art, love every single detail in the game and textures are great overall.
-scenery's were mind exploading!! i was amazed and truely astonished by looking at this peice of masterpeice done by their level design artists.

sound: 9.5/10
-sound overall was realistic and great.
-i loved the voice acting so much, i felt like im really inside this world and never wanted to leave.
  every gun shot, every explosion, every signel word recorded, all of these were done perfectly well in this game.
-i gave this category only 9.5/10 because there are some points that the player has to listen to some voice records of some  AI's but there is more happening in the game itself so it seems to like 'blend' it wrong sometimes. 
 dont get me wrong, this DOES NOT affect any of the gameplay i PROMISE you!!.

story/plot : 10/10:
-the plot was AMAZING! i really fell for this game, perfectly mind fucking plot that really keeps you waiting for the end of the game and then 'PSHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!' (your mind has just launchered from the top of your head!)
-'DAT ENDING DOE': the ending of this game was as amazing as the first one, andddddd... well the second one was great too... but gotta say that the first Bioschok and the third (this one) are the best of this series.
- the story rolls perfectly well and seems dynamic and logical, u dont ask much question like 'WTF?!!' or 'why didnt u go there beforeee u moronnn!' , the story is really well told!

gameplay/ game flow: 8.5/10
-the gameplay is smooth, really fun and also kinda funny. I LOVED IT!
-i gave it only 8.5 because of the really simple/casualy functioned combat system, but couldnt give it lower than 8.5 because however it was not the greatest combat system i would expect from a game like bioshock infinite, it still fits the game perfectly and serves all its needs to become a perfect shooting game with an amazing plot.
- YOU CANT NOT TO ENJOY THIS GAME!



overall, i FCKIN! recommand this game ! defently the one worth paying and playing, im so excited i would even finish this game once more, or even five times more! ( like i did with the first game hehe :P)

BUY THIS GAME!

My favourite of all times, the Bioshock triology. Infinite comes with a complex story, great graphics and an even greater battle system, keeping the certain atmosphere I love so much about it. The oldie songs do it for me. :D

Simply amazing. Story, Characters, Visuals, and Sound all some of the best I've seen in a while. Kept me hooked until I beat it. and I think I'll go digging through to find more in it. Booker and Elizebeth have one of the better relationships that's been presented in games today. They're people, caught in amazing circumstances, that's all.

Bioshock Infinite is among the best shooters of all time, though it very much is not without its problems. It streamlines a great deal of what people loved about the original Bioshock and once again delivers an incredible world with a fresh take on the classic hero saga.

The gunplay and abilities remain mostly unchanged - with similar upgrades and play-style balances that allow you to traverse the landscape in a manner of your choosing. The game seems a bit more linear than the first, which I don't mind quite as much as others. I appreciate a game that's a bit more directed than ones that leave you to your own devices.

For me though, the biggest draw is the story and the characters. Between exception sequences of cinematic livelihood and character exposition iks a game that really feels like you are in the middle of something so much bigger than yourself.  Even though the game is more linear and highly scripted in certain areas, the character immersion is there, making you feel that you have agency in how the game will conclude, even if the scope of actual changes are rather limited.

This game is incredible, from the level design and the incredible world of Columbia down to the characters, weapons, combat, and voice acting. Every facet of this game is truly a work of art, and the ending is so intricately planned that it will quite literally leave you speechless!

Fun game, however it is very short without the DLCs.  I would avoid this title at full price.  However, the story/gameplay does make it worthwhile to have in your collection if you can find this on the discount rack.

This game has such a good story to it, that and the rest of the serise, like its so confusing, but whatever, if you like games with a sexy story then this is the game for you, That and it looks gorgeous!!

Elegantly paced and continually mysterious. This somehow succeeded at leaving me guessing while not frustrating me with seemingly out-of-place, 11th-hour twists. The characters all oozed their unique personalities.

Combat is satisfying-the level design catered to several fighting styles while never allowing me to get complacent. Combining vigors with weapons is what I loved from the original, but the addition of sky-lines and gear to build your own fighting style made the experience fresh.

The soundtrack is pretty righteous, too.

Get it, if only for the line "go ahead Mr. DeWitt, I'll be fine down here." And she was.

Good story but the gameplay could be better.

I really love the Bioshock series.  I was a little less impressed with 2, but I've got to say Infinite is true to 1 (and it's predessessor, System Shock)'s form.  Gameplay has a nice, steady increase in difficulty.

I am getting so god-damn tired of all these obvious plot twists in games. Having just finished the formulaic Max Agony 7, I saw the plot twist from a mile off. You'd have to be Neil Kinnock to not see that Max was really a bald guy all along. So with that in mind here is Beushock Unlimited, the 4th installment in the Screwing Dante series. I've always been a fan of Ken Lemon's work, so I was eager to pick this copy up and play it, with no interruptions. You play as Dimwitt Brooks, a loan shark with limited brain function but a heart of gold. His 401k has been depleted by the dreaded Space Clocks, in an attempt to make the last 20 years of his life somewhat uncomfortable. Initially, I didn't know what to make of the plot, but then again I had doubts about the plot of Beushock Toxic when Mr. Lemon said it was going to be a remake of a reboot of the 2nd game; but we all know how that turned out, so I thought I'd at least hear him out on this one. As Brooks progresses through the game he gains his 401k back in installments, giving him powers called Randymids. This gives him the ability of being able to better invest his capital. Without giving away the ending, he gets his money back and lives happily ever after. So what did I think of the game? Well, it's hard to evaulate this as a game really. I'd say it's more like a work of arse. However, if someone put a gun to my head and told me to replay Max Agony 7, I'd  immediately give it three shattered pelvises out of femur.

This game was right around where I expected it to be.

Pros:
Very smooth with few bugs
Decent length with replayability and DLC
Great smooth visuals
Well told story
Great characters

Cons:
The powers are very limited in my opinion - you'll find yourself only ever using maybe one.
Guns were so-so

As far as the cons were concerned (limited as they were), the powers/vigors were simply limited to be. I never bothered using hardly any of them. Nothing in the game compelled me to use them (besides the occasional reminder text). While you can find plenty of Salt laying around (what powers the vigors), they get burned up in only a few uses and are usually only effective at stalling the enemy while you get in some good gun hits.

Speaking of about the available guns. I wish the capacities would have been a bit bigger - I was a decent shot, but found myself constantly having Elizabeth throwing ammo at me. The guns themselves were very similar, ugly, and mostly limited in their power. The only gun that stood out to me was the revolver. The game itself is worth it - especially if you can catch it on sale.

I'm not normally one to jump on major bandwagons. I usually assume triple A titles don't deserve the hype. I thought HL2 was overrated. I didn't finish the first bioshock, not because it wasn't a very good game, but because I got bored with it after a while. The difference between Bioshock and Infiinte is that it sucked me in from the beginning moment and gave a phenomenal storyline and set pieces until the end. I never thought that I would be okay quitting the game without being able to save, but it turns out I did because I genuinely wanted to replay parts of it. I can't say enough about how great the story is, but I'll try. As the narrative unfolds and the characters develop they deal with deeper and richer themes. What's great is how these themes interact with each other and feed the chaos until you reach the end.

TL; DR - This is better than Deus Ex 1 - gasp, I know.
This game is absolutly amazing! The Graphics are Amazing! The Story Is Amazing! The GamePlay Is Amazing! Everything Is Amazing!

Long have I played a game with such an immersive story and detailed characters that also act as a companion—Elizabeth. The game itself was a visual treat and though I'm an athiest, the heavy themes of religion and even race were so impactful for me so as to simply show that even utopia has its flaws.

The gameplay—specifically in regards to the vigors (spells)—is in my opinion way more smoother here than in the previous bioshocks. Mechanics in this game actually make you want to set up traps using a variety of vigors since pretty much any spell can become one a trigger-type trap. Furthermore, I felt that weapons depleted at a reasonable rate so as to motivate players to pick up and use other weapons, unlike in Bioshock 2 where my rivet gun was almost always full on ammo. Note also that the player can only hold 2 weapons at any given time in this game too.

The truly unique and most memorable part of this game for me was Booker's companion, Elizabeth. You will never complain about her combat abilites because she doesn't partake in it directly. In a way you will never even really notice that she is with you at times in combat, yet she aids in conjuring up cover and finding resources for you. In fact you will be thanking her when she hands you that extra coin she had just found which allows you to buy an upgrade that you previously didn't have enough for, or throwing you a health pack when you are just about to die. She is truly a gem of an AI and character in general; it even felt for the first half of the game like I was playing along with a Disney Princess. I mean come on, she even dances and sings in the game along with the fact that she looks like one!

Get this game, it is awesome. I should've gotten it sooner myself.

It is a really immersive game with a lot of things to do. It has just the right amount of challenge in my opinion and to top it all off this game looks absolutely stunning. I think the only down sides to this game are that you can only carry to weapons at a time and that it is autosave only, meaning you can't save when ever you want, so it can be an inconvenience when you don't have a lot of time to get through a level in order to save. But all and all this game is a 9/10 for me, if it wern't for those couple things it would be perfect.

While (in my opinion) it isn't as good as Bioshocks 1 and 2, Infinite is a phenomenal game that will make you question what you know about video games.
The story, as with all Bioshock games, is an original and complex one, that fully captivates the world it takes place in, and truly brings it to life. The art direction with this game is gorgeous, as well. The overall gameplay mechanics are stellar, and all the cool easter eggs are nice as well. The guns may be a tad bit generic, but they are well designed, and each one has it's own advantage in a gunfight.
Overall, Bioshock Infinite was a true masterpiece of a game, and should not be missed by anyone. It is the runner-up for my 2013 Game of The Year.

Amazing visuals, dependable gameplay, a truly unique setting, and a companion that actually helps instead of hinders all make Infinite the best Bioshock title and possibly the most reliably impressive FPS games to date.

Some people might not like the gameplay. Others will be turned off by how linear it is.

I'm here to tell you that none of this matters.

BioShock Infinite is a milestone in Video Game Storytelling. This is Pixar quality with Inception-level mind games. While I love the gameplay of Antichamber and the story of Stanley's Parable/Gone Home, BioShock Infinite is just as immersive with its subtlety beyond subtlety. The covers of popular songs, the uninterupted immersion due to death, the Luttece Twins laughing at your so-called choices and the beautiful artwork in every single nook and cranny skyrockets Infinite into my 2013 Game of the Year.

I felt the love that had been poured into this game. It didn't just fill me with awe and wonder, it broke my brain with the mind-shattering ending. It made me ponder the futility of free will. And just as there was backlash with ME3 and its ending, I welcome the masses who dismiss Infinite in any way. Because we're seeing a shift in gaming culture as we all get older. A shift towards caring more about prose and immersion and true roleplaying rather than just graphics or gameplay or bang for your buck.

Thank you, 2k Games, for allowing the masses to be able to read/watch/play this game while not dumbing down the message or story. If this future-past is the future of games, then I welcome it with open arms.

I like this game. It's bursting with life and atmosphere that it's just a joy to play around in the world above the clouds.

If you love a good story with a game that's fun, this is a game for you!

It's a game about infinite possibilities and how everything really is of no consequence. Your enjoyment of this game will hinge largely on your ability to suspend your disbelieve and to not think too much about the mechanics or interactions of/with the game world. Hopefully you also have a very strong believe that “it’s about the journey, not the destination” (which I can’t explain further because of spoilers). This game wants you to think about its ending and the impactions ONLY, and not too much about the game itself.

The gameplay is fairly average, competent but not engaging. Gunplay feels very limited despite the large selection of guns due to the player’s inability to hold more than 2 guns at a time and limited resources mean that you’ll only get to upgrade certain weapons. The fun of using vigors wear thin after a while and combat just becomes a chore as you mow down waves of enemies to get to the next plot point. The Skylines are the only fun mechanic in the game but isn’t prevalent enough to make a significant difference to the overall combat experience. Overall, gameplay doesn’t feel quite satisfying enough to justify a recommendation. It’s not terrible, but since combat is the only gameplay mechanic other than savaging for resources, its mediocrity is pretty detrimental to the overall experience of the game.

The story is smart and complex but suffers from pacing issues. Most of the plot bookends the game, sandwiching several hours of boring filler where little to nothing of consequence occurs. And although the game’s twist is lauded by many to be the best in recent memory, it’s honestly not that surprising when you discover the game’s themes, nor is it very unique or unexpected for a sci-fi fantasy plot. The game is also very linear, where you basically follow the plot railroad from point to point. There is little consequence to any of your actions or choices in the game and the player has absolutely no influence on the plot.
Overall the story had very little impact on me, and even though there were several emotional moments near the end of the game, the story ultimately feels meaningless and empty, neither happy or sad, nor triumphant or disappointing. It’s still a very smart story but fails to connect with me on any emotional level.

The game’s environments are beautiful and striking, but since the same can be said about most AAA titles nowadays, so such praise is entirely superfluous and entirely dependent on the player. It’s neither the most aesthetically impressive nor the most technically impressive game I’ve seen.

Ultimately, I feel that the game is an interesting thought exercise packaged in a fairly mediocre game. It was a game created to service a story, and to me, it sacrificed too much gameplay to achieve it. The story would have been much better conveyed in a movie/series/comic/book.

Bioshock Infinite is a very engrossing game, even if a bit short.  The "plasmids" of this installment in the Bioshock series have little explanation.  "What's in this bottle?"  "Why, super powers, my boy!" Beyond that, the story is interesting and worth playing through and graphics are very well polished.  With the introduction of some support characters (Elizabeth and Songbird), death is more common in this one than in previous Bioshock games, but the city in the sky, Columbia, offers new weapons and abilities that hold your attention nicely, even if the game is a bit short.

Every bit as fun as the original.  From the story and the twists and turns that it throws at you to just the overall environment, this game had me hooked from the very beginning.  With enhanced controlling aspects that allow you to quickly switch on the fly (uber helpful) to the ability to mix and match your special abilities with your shooting aspects, this is just all around better.  

While having not played any of the DLC yet, I do look forward to exploring that realm as well.  For those who are trepidatious about buying this game, I saw buy it now.  For those that want to wait, wait for it to go on sale.  But this is definitely a game, that I think, should be on every gamers "should play" list.

This is such a great game. I've just beat it and I think it's fair to say it has the best story and best ending of all the games I have ever played. I don't want to spoil the fun for you, but everything gets really weird and mind-blowing near the end. Apart from the fantastic storytelling, you also get a beautifully crafted, living and full of secrets world and a satisfying, balanced gameplay experience. Infinite is the first Bioshock I've played, but it sure as hell isn't the last. I suggest you go buy it now, when it's on sale and play it. You won't be disappointed.
